docs.lead_paragraph: Edging into one of the most politically combustible issues facing the nation, President Clinton urged Congress tonight not to spend any budget surpluses the Federal Government might enjoy in coming years until the two parties solve the Social Security system's looming financial problems. Mr. Clinton proposed no specific remedies for Social Security, and he stopped short of insisting that the entire fiscal windfall go toward shoring up the retirement program.

headline.main: Fixing Social Security Should Come Before Any Surplus Free-for-All, President Says
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: DOMESTIC PLANS

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton outlines domestic programs in State of Union address; urges Congress not to spend any budget surplus until resolving Social Security's looming financial problems; seeks to avoid partisan fight on issue; asks Congress to extend reach of 1993 law to guarantee family and medical leave for 10 million more workers; proposes major spending increases by National Institutes of Health on biomedical research; proposes raising institute's budget by $1.15 billion next year and 50 percent over five years; urges Congress to let people age 55 to 64 buy Medicare coverage; urges Congress to back his new package of child care proposals; graphs (L)

headline.main: Transcript of the State of the Union Message From President Clinton

docs.abstract: Text of Pres Clinton's State of Union Message; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Following is President Clinton's State of the Union Message, as transcribed by The New York Times:      Mr. Speaker, Mr. Vice President, members of the 105th Congress, distinguished guests, and my fellow Americans:

docs.lead_paragraph: Labor costs rose at the fastest pace in five years in the last quarter of 1997, bringing the annual increase in total compensation to 3.3 percent. The news, which immediately raised some inflationary fears, was enough to send bond prices sharply lower. But the stock market seemed to ignore the report, although many economists say higher compensation would lead to lower earnings as many companies swallow the added costs because competition, especially from Asia, would prevent them from raising prices. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 102.14 points, to 7,815.08.

headline.main: Prices Tumble on a Report Showing Rising Labor Costs

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports Employee Cost Index rose 1 percent in fourth quarter, up from increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous two quarters; wages and salaries were up 1.1 percent, largest increase in seven and a half years, while cost of employee benefits rose nine tenths of 1 percent, largest increase since third quarter of 1994; annual increase in total compensation was 3.3 percent; bond prices rise sharply; 30-year Treasury bond's price falls 18/32, to 102 22/32; yield rises to 5.93 percent, from 5.89 percent on Jan 26; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton, facing the gravest personal and political peril in a crisis-prone career, emerged from the darkness shrouding his Presidency for more than an hour tonight to proclaim the state of the Union sound and to propose a plan to rescue Social Security. Swathed in bright television lights and enveloped in the grandeur of the House chamber, the President was met by a thunderous ovation from both sides of the aisle as he arrived at 9:09 P.M. to deliver his annual State of the Union address. On a rainy night in a scandal-fevered capital, the political world suspended its speculation on Mr. Clinton's personal and legal future and focused, if distractedly, on his political program.

headline.main: CLINTON, WITH CRISIS SWIRLING, PUTS FOCUS ON SOCIAL SECURITY IN UPBEAT STATE OF UNION TALK
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton delivers State of Union address, greeted by applause from Congress; proposes billions of dollars of new spending on social programs, paid for through closing unspecified tax loopholes and billions of dollars in tobacco taxes aimed at discouraging smoking by young people; calls for using any budget surplus to shore up Social Security system; Sen Trent Lott delivers Republican response, holding Clinton offers vision of more Government, while Republicans promise smaller Government and lower taxes; photos; table (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The accusations that President Clinton had an affair with a White House intern have not dimmed the public's view of how he is handling his job, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken over the weekend. The findings suggest that Americans may be willing to look beyond Mr. Clinton's personal troubles because they are generally satisfied with their lives and pleased with the economy. The President's handling of his job remains high at 56 percent, virtually unchanged from 58 percent in a Times/CBS News Poll in December. His ratings on the economy and foreign policy are the highest of his Presidency.

headline.main: Clinton Job Rating Remains High Despite Doubts on Moral Values
headline.kicker: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE PUBLIC VIEW

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll finds allegations of sexual misconduct, involving Pres Clinton and former White House intern Monica S Lewinsky, have not dimmed public's view of how he is handling his job; suggest Americans may be willing to look beyond his personal troubles because they are generally satisfied with their lives and pleased with economy; finds rating for Clinton's handling of job remains high at 56 percent, virtually unchanged from 58 percent in December 1997; ratings on economy and foreign policy are highest of Presidency, even though people are now less likely than they once were to say he shares moral values that most Americans try to live by; other findings discussed; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton proposed today to spend nearly $25 billion over the next decade on reducing class sizes in elementary schools, building and renovating schools and addressing a variety of other problems in the nation's education system. White House officials said the proposals would be highlighted by Mr. Clinton in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, along with a host of other policy initiatives the Administration has outlined in recent weeks. Those include expanding health insurance coverage for early retirees, addressing the looming problems in Social Security and increasing spending on food safety and inspection.

headline.main: Clinton Proposes Spending $25 Billion on Education
headline.kicker: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE MESSAGE

docs.lead_paragraph: There is no use pretending otherwise -- Bill Clinton's appearance before the nation tonight to deliver the State of the Union address cannot help but be an awkward occasion for the President and the American people. Much attention will be given to whether Mr. Clinton makes any mention of the accusations of criminal and sexual misconduct that have transfixed Washington for the last week. Everything from Hillary Rodham Clinton's expression to the level of applause in the House chamber will be closely watched. Neither the media nor the public can be blamed for this. They are not the ones who made listening to the chief executive into a semantic guessing game. Even so, it would be a disservice to the country if Mr. Clinton's policy statements are not closely attended to. Americans can afford to take a time-out from the Clinton scandals tonight and concentrate on the Clinton proposals. On the legal side, most Americans are still undecided about whether crimes were committed. They are also reserving a final political judgment about whether Mr. Clinton should continue in office. The President has delayed too long in addressing these matters, in our view, but as a practical matter the state of uncertainty will remain for some time. Though yesterday he emphatically repeated his denial that he had had sexual relations with Monica Lewinsky or had asked her or anyone else to lie about it, he must soon provide a full account of his association with the former White House intern. But for this evening, at least, there is other business to conduct.
docs.abstract: Editorial says, despite allegations of sexual misconduct swirling around Pres Clinton, Americans should take time out during his State of the Union address to concentrate on his proposals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the fourth floor of a factory in Long Island City, Queens, Clifton Harrell deftly handles heavy machinery to trim, bend and assemble toilet bowl brushes, 150 dozen a day. His hands are a blur; his body, a study in efficient motion. ''It's a lot of work, but once you get used to it, it's like clockwork,'' said Mr. Harrell, wiping a bead of sweat from his forehead. Then, cocking his head toward the ground, he added, ''And I got Austin here.''

headline.main: Separate Jobs for Blind Spur a Spirited Debate

docs.abstract: Article discusses debate over whether blind are better served by jobs that are tailored for them or by mainstream employment; various opinions discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Irish soldiers, who have never in this country's 75 years of proud independence had occasion to fire a shot in defense of the homeland, are now engaged in war -- or at least extended skirmishing -- with their own Government. The fight -- which has caused a debate, sometimes humorous, in newspapers and on radio and television -- is over court claims by about 3,000 soldiers that the Government should compensate them for a hearing loss. The soldiers, about a quarter of the total number in uniform, say that their hearing has been impaired by the boom of cannons, albeit during practice, and by the stutter of automatic weapons fire.

headline.main: Were the Guns Too Loud? Irish Soldiers Take Issue to Court

docs.abstract: Approximately 3,000 Irish soldiers are locked in dispute with Government, claiming that they should be compensated for hearing loss; say hearing has been impaired by boom of cannons, albeit during practice, and by stutter of automatic weapons fire; Government says most of claimants are malingerers, who have hired smart lawyers (M)
